text:
Eighth Avenue, east side, north from W. 44th Street, showing thoroughfare that in 1938 shows a decided change. The completion of the Municipal Subway in 1930 was the major cause. The 44th-45th Street block front will shortly be cleared and upon same will rise the magnificent Hotel Lincoln. Note at the left the former Knights of Columbus building and hotel under construction and which subsequently changed its name after readjustment of taxability about 1936.

June 1925.

Eighth Ave., east side, north from and including West 44th Street. Prominent building under construction is the Hotel Lincoln.

June 1927.

Eighth Avenue, west side, from 45th to 44th Streets.
October 14, 1927.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Eighth Avenue, at, adjoining and south of the S. E. corner of W. 44th Street, as photographed across the excavation at the N. W. corner of 43rd Street.
Shown at No. 690-2 Eighth Avenue is the building containing the Gospel Tabernacle. View 2 is limited to this structure.

View 1: February 1, 1928
View 2: May 27, 1931

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, at, adjoining and south of the S. E. corner of W. 44th Street, as photographed across the excavation at the N. W. corner of 43rd Street.
Shown at No. 690-2 Eighth Avenue is the building containing the Gospel Tabernacle. View 2 is limited to this structure.

View 1: February 1, 1928
View 2: May 27, 1931

P. L. Sperr

332-334 West 44th Street, south side, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. No. 332 is a four story frame building. 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York. Negative No. 199

Interior Whelan's Drug Store
44th St. & 8th Ave. no.700 8th Ave. Feb. 7, 1936 Neg. 67 (Museum of the City of NY

Berenice Abbott, photographer
